conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light from a source, creating a dark area on the surface behind the object. The size and position of the shadow depend on the angle and distance of the light source relative to the object.

In the image, there are four objects: a mushroom (casting shadow A), a sculpture (casting shadow B), a dress (casting shadow C), and a book (casting shadow D). The light source is currently positioned above these objects, casting shadows on the ground.

premise: When the light source moves forward (towards the top of the image), it changes the angle at which light hits the objects.
conclusion: This will affect both the position and size of the shadows.

premise: As the light source moves forward, the angle of incidence on the objects becomes steeper.
conclusion: The shadows will generally become longer.

premise: The light source moves forward, changing the angle of incidence.
conclusion: Shadow A (Mushroom) will move backward (towards the bottom of the image).
